apple did it a couple of years ago with one of their product landing pages… now they don’t

lol you scrap what doesn’t work
i actually dont get the part "that does not work" though. I mean, yeah its kinda weird and not what people are used to, but does that automatically render it useless?
so everything that is not "traditional" and none of thoses things that are "set in stone" ? is useless in terms of  UX ??
I think it would be interesting to see some heatmaps and user interaction on this.  I would also be interested to see their visitor breakdown based on device

There was a lot of uproar and complaints when Apple tried to push scroll jacking. There’s nothing wrong with pushing design trends… but you better be careful when scrapping UX data and best practices for the sake of being unique.

Again, there’s a reason a lot of companies who tried scroll jacking years ago have stopped.
But if you are gonna implement horizontal scrolling, <https://medium.com/@paonecreative_87456/scrolljacking-the-usability-nightmare-2a5bbb4273d0|here is a good article>
With a standard scroll wheel it feels odd. However, with my touchpad it feels ok.
It breaks keyboard navigation (no pgup/down) etc, so i imagine that’s a nono for usability
